title: Thailand MICE Exchange 2026 set for April in Bangkok - Travel Daily News Asia-Pacific
authors: Theodore Koumelis, Theodore Koumelis https:, www.traveldailynews.asia, theodore-koumelis, theodore.koumelis
description:
TMX 2026 will gather global MICE professionals in Bangkok, focusing on innovation, sustainability, business networking, and strategic industry growth.
BANGKOK, THAILAND – The Thai Exhibition Association (TEA) has confirmed that the next edition of Thailand MICE Exchange 2026 (TMX 2026) will take place from 29th to 30th April 2026 at the Queen Sirikit National Convention Center (QSNCC) in Bangkok.
Held under the theme “Innovation & Sustainability: Powering Excellence & Growth in Thailand’s MICE Industry”, TMX 2026 will serve as Thailand’s annual exhibition and conference platform for the MICE industry.
Organized by TEA in partnership with the Thailand Convention and Exhibition Bureau (TCEB), TMX 2026 is expected to gather 100 local and international MICE exhibitors.
TMX 2026 aims to act as a catalyst for growth, positioning Thailand as both a destination for events and a platform for business acceleration.
text:
TMX 2026 will gather global MICE professionals in Bangkok, focusing on innovation, sustainability, business networking, and strategic industry growth.

BANGKOK, THAILAND – The Thai Exhibition Association (TEA) has confirmed that the next edition of Thailand MICE Exchange 2026 (TMX 2026) will take place from 29th to 30th April 2026 at the Queen Sirikit National Convention Center (QSNCC) in Bangkok.

Held under the theme “Innovation & Sustainability: Powering Excellence & Growth in Thailand’s MICE Industry”, TMX 2026 will serve as Thailand’s annual exhibition and conference platform for the MICE industry. The event aims to elevate Thailand’s MICE sector by driving innovation and sustainability while acting as a premier venue for knowledge exchange.

Organized by TEA in partnership with the Thailand Convention and Exhibition Bureau (TCEB), TMX 2026 is expected to gather 100 local and international MICE exhibitors. More than 4,000 trade delegates from Thailand and Southeast Asia are anticipated, with the exhibition showcasing business events, travel products, services, and solutions.

The program will feature two main conference tracks: the Main Stage and the X-Change Square. The Main Stage will host high-level C-suite discussions on growth, profitability, risk, future trends, and leadership. In parallel, the X-Change Square will focus on practical knowledge-sharing and MICE operations. Together, these tracks will deliver over 30 sessions with more than 61 speakers, attracting an estimated 1,400 attendees.

A highlight of the event will be the Business Matching Program, expected to facilitate over 360 pre-arranged one-to-one meetings between buyers and sellers across the two days.

The organizers emphasize that Thailand is positioning itself not only as a host destination but also as a comprehensive business ecosystem and strategic gateway linking global companies with ASEAN and the Greater Mekong subregion. With a strong track record of hosting thousands of business events, Thailand continues to strengthen its role as a regional MICE powerhouse.

According to TEA, TMX 2026 will provide participants with opportunities to generate leads, expand market share, build brand awareness, launch new products and services, and gain insights into the trends shaping the MICE industry.

TMX 2026 aims to act as a catalyst for growth, positioning Thailand as both a destination for events and a platform for business acceleration.

title: MSGA Directors Sound Economic Warning in Meeting with Sen. Klobuchar
description:
Not so, Klobuchar said during a visit to the Tyler, Minn., farm of Joel Schreurs, a director with the Minnesota Soybean Growers Association (MSGA).
Since April 2025, when trade tensions between China and the U.S. began increasing, China has effectively stopped purchasing U.S. soybeans.
“It’s a perfect storm of ugly.” Joel Schreurs underscored the importance of agriculture to rural towns throughout Minnesota and the country.

text:
ST. PAUL, Minn. — Prior to attending the 40th Farm Aid benefit concert Sept. 20 in Minneapolis, Sen. Amy Klobuchar felt that perhaps the emerging crisis unfolding in the farm economy had fallen on deaf ears across the country.

Not so, Klobuchar said during a visit to the Tyler, Minn., farm of Joel Schreurs, a director with the Minnesota Soybean Growers Association (MSGA).

The dire message is being received.

“After Farm Aid, I think people are waking up to how bad it is right now (in agriculture),” she said during a roundtable discussion in Schreurs’ garage, where she was flanked by Schreurs and MSGA Director Bob Worth. “It’s gotten into their psyche, and I think they’re starting to see it.”

Worth said the current economic landscape reminded him of conditions that led to the creation of Farm Aid four decades ago.

“This is the 1980s farm crisis all over again,” Worth said.

Tariffs on many of U.S. soy’s largest trading partners have wreaked havoc on not just producers, but the entire ag supply chain. Since April 2025, when trade tensions between China and the U.S. began increasing, China has effectively stopped purchasing U.S. soybeans. In the 2023/2024 marketing year, China imported over $13 billion in U.S. soybeans. Replacing that market takes years, not weeks or months. Additionally, in contrast to the 2018-2019 trade war, tariffs have gone beyond China to affect U.S. soy customers across the globe. Combine low commodity prices with a widening basis and input costs that remain stubbornly high, and it’s hard to look for a bright economic spot as farmers head out into the fields to harvest what’s predicted to be a near-record soybean crop.

“It’s a weird combination of bad circumstances,” Klobuchar said, adding, “We’ve got to find a way out.”

Matt Schreurs, Joel’s cousin and vice president of ag lending with First Farmers and Merchant Bank, explained to the senator that the numbers aren’t adding up for producers in his region. Some growers are seeing losses totaling $180 per acre.

“I’m looking at a lot of red ink,” said Matt Schreurs, a member of MSGA. “It’s a perfect storm of ugly.”

Joel Schreurs underscored the importance of agriculture to rural towns throughout Minnesota and the country. He’s also concerned how younger farmers will be impacted.

“When ag does well in southwest Minnesota, so does our local economy,” he said.

Instead of wallowing in bad news, Joel, Matt, Worth and Executive Director Joe Smentek offered a series of recommendations to Sen. Klobuchar that could lead to economic improvement across farm country in the months ahead:

Removal of tariffs on U.S. soybeans through negotiations

Unfreeze USAID funding. Food aid programs through USAID help build a positive, long-tern reputation for U.S. agriculture across decades. In FY2024, about $110 million worth of U.S. soy was purchased by USAID for Food for Peace

Passing a skinny Farm Bill before year’s end to ensure critical programs continue to receive funding

Supporting renewable fuels through higher blends of biodiesel and using soybean oil as a primary feedstock in sustainable aviation fuel

“There’s got to be some sort of resolution,” Klobuchar said.

Without a trade deal with China, the farmers agreed, financial assistance will likely be warranted to prevent a full-blown catastrophe in the ag economy.

“Farmers want open markets more than anything, but the current situation is unsustainable,” Joel Schreurs said. “We’re going to lose a lot of good farmers without an assistance package.”

Joel Schreurs, who sits on the board of the U.S. Soybean Export Council (USSEC), thanked the senator, the ranking Democrat on the Senate Agriculture Committee, for supporting policies that are helping to grow market access beyond China and invited her to visit emerging markets that are working with USSEC through the Soy Excellence Center.

“We had great discussions and let her know what we’re thinking and where we want to go from here,” he said.

Schreurs’ efforts to grow markets continue. On Sept. 30, he’s hosting a Southeast Asian trade delegation alongside Northern Soy Marketing.

–Minnesota Soybean Growers Association

title: Exolum proyecta una nueva terminal de graneles líquidos en Punta Langosteira con una ...
description:
Exolum ha iniciado los trámites de autorización para construir una terminal de almacenamiento de graneles líquidos en el Puerto Exterior de A Coruña, en la dársena de Punta Langosteira.
La inversión prevista supera los 100 millones de euros, según informó la compañía.
La terminal estaría habilitada para operar con productos convencionales y combustibles sostenibles como amoniaco renovable, CO₂ capturado, metanol verde, SAF (Sustainable Aviation Fuel) y biocarburantes.
Estos equipos permitirán almacenar combustibles de bajas emisiones, productos químicos, amoniaco y CO₂.
También señaló que el Puerto Exterior de A Coruña ofrece condiciones operativas, accesibilidad marítima y conexiones multimodales adecuadas para este tipo de proyectos.
text:
Exolum ha iniciado los trámites de autorización para construir una terminal de almacenamiento de graneles líquidos en el Puerto Exterior de A Coruña, en la dársena de Punta Langosteira. La inversión prevista supera los 100 millones de euros, según informó la compañía.

El proyecto se plantea como una instalación de transición energética preparada para adaptarse a la evolución normativa, del mercado y de la demanda industrial. La terminal estaría habilitada para operar con productos convencionales y combustibles sostenibles como amoniaco renovable, CO₂ capturado, metanol verde, SAF (Sustainable Aviation Fuel) y biocarburantes.

El diseño contempla una capacidad aproximada de 165.000 metros cúbicos, distribuidos en varios tanques atmosféricos, criogénicos y presurizados, ubicados en dos parcelas diferenciadas pero conectadas. Estos equipos permitirán almacenar combustibles de bajas emisiones, productos químicos, amoniaco y CO₂. La infraestructura incluiría un cargadero ferroviario de ancho ibérico con conexión directa a la red nacional, enlaces a dos atraques para buques mediante una red de tuberías y bombas de gran capacidad, además de isletas de carga para camiones cisterna y sistemas auxiliares de seguridad y operación.

Las actividades previstas abarcan el almacenamiento, mezcla y expedición de biodiésel, HVO, bioetanol, metanol, naftas, SAF, materias primas para biocombustibles e hidrocarburos tradicionales, así como operaciones de blending y distribución multimodal. En el caso del CO₂ criogénico, la planta está concebida para su recepción, almacenamiento en condiciones presurizadas y refrigeradas, y expedición tanto marítima como terrestre, con opción de conexión futura por ducto. El amoniaco podría llegar por vía marítima o terrestre, almacenarse en tanques criogénicos y distribuirse mediante distintos medios de transporte.

El proyecto busca configurarse como una infraestructura logística multimodal e integrada, orientada a optimizar el sistema logístico regional, incrementar la eficiencia operativa y garantizar un suministro energético seguro y sostenible en Galicia y el noroeste peninsular.

Debido a la complejidad de la instalación y a la diversidad de productos que manejará, la entrada en funcionamiento será escalonada. Exolum prevé iniciar las operaciones en 2029.

La compañía considera que la futura terminal reforzará la posición del Puerto de A Coruña como nodo logístico de referencia en Europa, con conexiones hacia el norte del continente, América, el sur de Europa y Oriente Medio.

Jorge Guillén, Aviation & Spain Network Lead de Exolum, explicó que la iniciativa responde a la necesidad de nuevas infraestructuras logísticas que acompañen la transición energética. También señaló que el Puerto Exterior de A Coruña ofrece condiciones operativas, accesibilidad marítima y conexiones multimodales adecuadas para este tipo de proyectos.

Exolum estima que la terminal contribuirá a la competitividad de la economía gallega, con generación de empleo cualificado durante la construcción y operación, así como atracción de inversiones relacionadas con la descarbonización y el desarrollo de moléculas verdes.

title: UAE Announces Winners Of $1 Million SMBR Global Aviation Award - OneArabia
description:
Local -OneArabia The UAE recently celebrated the winners of the third Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum Global Aviation Award (SMBR), distributing a total prize of USD 1 million.
The event highlighted the UAE's commitment to advancing global civil aviation through research and development.
The SMBR Global Aviation Award reflects the UAE’s pioneering role in supporting the aviation industry and enhancing its position as an incubator for initiatives that inspire the world and advance sustainability."
Commitment to Global Cooperation The UAE has implemented significant measures towards sustainability, including a roadmap for sustainable aviation fuel production.
Initiatives like a digital platform for CORSIA (Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation) have been developed alongside establishing the Global Sustainable Aviation Marketplace (GSAM).
text:
Local

-OneArabia

The UAE recently celebrated the winners of the third Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum Global Aviation Award (SMBR), distributing a total prize of USD 1 million. This award recognises excellence in aviation, with a focus on sustainability and innovation. The event highlighted the UAE's commitment to advancing global civil aviation through research and development.

Abdulla bin Touq Al Marri, Minister of Economy and Tourism and Chairman of the UAE General Civil Aviation Authority (GCAA), stated: "The SMBR Global Aviation Award embodies the UAE’s commitment to supporting research and innovation, motivating young talents and research institutions to develop practical and sustainable solutions that will shape the future of global civil aviation."

The third edition of the award concentrated on sustainability, particularly sustainable aviation fuel solutions. This aligns with international goals for carbon neutrality by 2050. The UAE's role in fostering innovation and global cooperation was evident through this initiative. The award is organised every three years in collaboration with ICAO, having been launched in 2016.

Winners in the Academic Research and Development category hailed from universities in Brazil, the United States, and Kazakhstan. Meanwhile, the German Aerospace Center (DLR) secured victory in the Research Institutions category. These achievements underscore the global reach and impact of the award.

During the 42nd Assembly of the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO), Abdulla Al Marri delivered an official statement emphasising aviation as a bridge for human communication. He noted that under UAE leadership, aviation has become central to national vision and global mission, with 189 air service agreements reflecting open skies as key to shared prosperity.

Saif Mohammed Al Suwaidi, Director General of the GCAA, remarked: "We are proud to host this reception as a platform to honor innovators and showcase their achievements to global aviation leaders. The SMBR Global Aviation Award reflects the UAE’s pioneering role in supporting the aviation industry and enhancing its position as an incubator for initiatives that inspire the world and advance sustainability."

Commitment to Global Cooperation

The UAE has implemented significant measures towards sustainability, including a roadmap for sustainable aviation fuel production. Initiatives like a digital platform for CORSIA (Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation) have been developed alongside establishing the Global Sustainable Aviation Marketplace (GSAM).

Al Marri further stated: "The UAE believes that progress in aviation cannot be achieved unless it includes everyone, and sustainability can only be realized through investment in human capital. To this end, the UAE has developed several initiatives to build sector competencies in collaboration with its international partners."

The evening saw an official state reception hosted by the UAE in Montreal as part of ICAO assembly protocol. This event blended formalities with cultural elements, attended by ministers, civil aviation directors from ICAO member states, and officials from regional and international organisations.

He added: "The UAE has repeatedly opened its doors to host the world, serving as a hub for partners, a supportive voice for international cooperation, and a bridge between regions as a trusted and constructive ally." This highlights their ongoing dedication to fostering international partnerships within aviation.

With inputs from WAM

Story first published: Sunday, September 28, 2025, 19:00 [GST]

title: World Tourism Day 2025 Signals Sector's Shift to Sustainability and Digital Innovation
description:
Global tourism leaders used World Tourism Day 2025 in Melaka, Malaysia, to chart a new course for the sector — one built on sustainability, innovation and digital transformation to drive long-term resilience and inclusive growth.
Under the theme “Tourism and Sustainable Transformation”, the celebrations underscored how the industry is moving beyond recovery to become a catalyst for social progress, economic opportunity, and environmental stewardship.
Hosted by the World Tourism Organization (UN Tourism) in partnership with Malaysia’s Ministry of Tourism, Arts and Culture, the event coincided with the 7th World Tourism Conference (WTC), bringing together ministers, policymakers, and industry leaders to exchange ideas and set priorities for the next stage of tourism’s evolution.
“World Tourism Day 2025 in Melaka has shown the world that tourism can be a force for good when guided by sustainability and inclusivity,” UN Tourism Secretary-General Zurab Pololikashvili said.
Yet, it must be sustainable to protect the very places and communities it celebrates.” Looking ahead, UN Tourism’s secretary-general, Pololikashvili, stressed that World Tourism Day 2025 marks the start of a new chapter for the sector.
text:
Global tourism leaders used World Tourism Day 2025 in Melaka, Malaysia, to chart a new course for the sector — one built on sustainability, innovation and digital transformation to drive long-term resilience and inclusive growth.

Under the theme “Tourism and Sustainable Transformation”, the celebrations underscored how the industry is moving beyond recovery to become a catalyst for social progress, economic opportunity, and environmental stewardship.

Hosted by the World Tourism Organization (UN Tourism) in partnership with Malaysia’s Ministry of Tourism, Arts and Culture, the event coincided with the 7th World Tourism Conference (WTC), bringing together ministers, policymakers, and industry leaders to exchange ideas and set priorities for the next stage of tourism’s evolution.

The gathering highlighted the need for good governance, strategic planning and inclusive policies to ensure that tourism’s benefits reach local communities while protecting cultural and natural heritage.

Malaysia used the occasion to showcase its own initiatives — from expanding high-value tourism segments and digital nomad hubs to investing in sustainable aviation fuel and community-led ecotourism. It also announced plans to join the UN Tourism International Network of Sustainable Tourism Observatories (INSTO) with a pilot project in Mersing, Johor, reinforcing its commitment to measuring and managing tourism’s impact.

“World Tourism Day 2025 in Melaka has shown the world that tourism can be a force for good when guided by sustainability and inclusivity,” UN Tourism Secretary-General Zurab Pololikashvili said. “By working together, we can transform tourism into a tool for empowerment, cultural preservation, and environmental protection.”

Speakers throughout the day emphasized the pillars of sustainable transformation: investing in education and skills, especially for women, youth, and marginalized groups; accelerating innovation and digital transformation by supporting start-ups and closing the “digital gap”; promoting micro and small enterprises to strengthen local economies; and preserving cultural heritage as a cornerstone of authentic travel experiences.

“Tourism is a powerful driver of transformation,” said UN Secretary-General António Guterres in his official message. “It creates jobs, fuels local economies, and builds bridges across cultures. Yet, it must be sustainable to protect the very places and communities it celebrates.”

Looking ahead, UN Tourism’s secretary-general, Pololikashvili, stressed that World Tourism Day 2025 marks the start of a new chapter for the sector.

Malaysia formally handed over the hosting of World Tourism Day to El Salvador for 2026, which will take place under the theme “Digital Agenda and Artificial Intelligence to Redesign Tourism”, setting the stage for the industry’s next wave of innovation and transformation.

Follow to keep up to date with all the latest on tourism and travel in Greece.

title: The Bear Cave #293 - by Edwin Dorsey - Substack
description:
Welcome to The Bear Cave!
New Activist Reports Morpheus Research published a 14,222-word report on Brunello Cucinelli (Milan: BC — EUR5.67 billion), a luxury Italian clothing brand.
Jehoshaphat Research published a 54-page report on goeasy (Toronto: GSY — CAD$2.80 billion), a Canadian subprime lender.
Fugazi Research published on Brera Holdings (NASDAQ: BREA — $75 million), an Irish holding company that owns four association soccer clubs and one volleyball club.
He also said he had an undisclosed personal trading account that invested in the same instruments as Greenlight at around the same time.” Tweets of the Week Until Thursday, The Bear Cave New?
text:
Welcome to The Bear Cave! Our last premium articles were “Problems at Gogo (GOGO)” and “Problems at DraftKings (DKNG)” and our next special investigation comes out this Thursday, October 2.

New Activist Reports

Morpheus Research published a 14,222-word report on Brunello Cucinelli (Milan: BC — EUR5.67 billion), a luxury Italian clothing brand. Morpheus largely alleged that Brunello Cucinelli was violating EU sanctions on the sale of luxury goods to Russia based on import data, interviews with former executives, and photos from secret shoppers showing the company’s active presence in Russia.

Morpheus also said that Brunello Cucinelli “has resorted to aggressive discounting to manage bloated inventory” and “trades at ~46x next year’s earnings, a higher multiple than any luxury peer, despite slowing revenue growth, average operating margins, and rising competition.”

Blue Orca Capital published on Aya Gold & Silver (Toronto: AYA — CAD$2.08 billion), a Canadian silver mining company with operations in Morocco. Blue Orca alleged that “there is overwhelming evidence that Aya inflated its silver resource at Zgounder, its only producing asset, by over 100%, potentially reflecting as many as 50+ million phantom ounces.” Blue Orca specifically raised concerns about the legitimacy of a bullish December 2021 resource estimate report for the company’s mine. Blue Orca alleged that the resource estimate was “created by a conflicted geologist who appears to be a close business partner of the CEO” and had other anomalies which suggest the report data was manipulated to show artificially inflated silver reserves.

Jehoshaphat Research published a 54-page report on goeasy (Toronto: GSY — CAD$2.80 billion), a Canadian subprime lender. Jehoshaphat alleged the company “is sitting on ~$300m worth of improperly delayed credit losses and unreported serious delinquencies that have been buried in the balance sheet like dead bodies in the snow.” Jehoshaphat highlighted that the company has recently “changed its accounting rules for charge-offs, credit risk scoring, and expense recognition,” which has “pushed hundreds of millions worth of bad debt and other expenses into the future.” Jehoshaphat also raised concerns about the recent departures of the company’s CEO and CFO, as well as high insider selling by company executives.

Fugazi Research published on Brera Holdings (NASDAQ: BREA — $75 million), an Irish holding company that owns four association soccer clubs and one volleyball club. Fugazi raised concerns about the company’s recent pivot to a “digital asset treasury” model that would likely lead to high levels of shareholder dilution.

BMF Reports published on US Gold Corp (NASDAQ: USAU — $233 million), a Nevada-based gold miner that BMF alleged is engaged in paid stock promotion and has “heavy dilution risk ahead.”

Recent Resignations

Notable executive departures disclosed in the past week include:

CEO of Portillo’s (NASDAQ: PTLO — $476 million) “departed the company as President and CEO and as a member of the Board of Directors” with immediate effect after seven years. In June 2024, the company’s Chief Operating Officer departed after three years. The company is down ~85% since its October 2021 IPO.

Ms. Safra Catz, who served as CEO and CFO of Oracle (NYSE: ORCL — $806 billion), “will take on a new role as Executive Vice Chair of the Board” after 11 years of leadership. Oracle stock rose by over 600% during her tenure.

Board member of XCF Global (NASDAQ: SAFX — $221 million), Ms. Anne Anderson, resigned effective immediately after just three months “for personal reasons.” The sustainable aviation fuel company is down ~85% since its June 2025 SPAC merger.

Chair of S&T Bancorp (NASDAQ: STBA — $1.47 billion) resigned after seven years following “her confirmation as an ambassador to Sweden by the United States Senate.”

Data for this section is provided by VerityData from VerityPlatform.com

News of the Week

“Idea Brunch with Steven Grey of Grey Value Management” (Sunday’s Idea Brunch)

“Prior to launching Grey Value Management in 2010 and the Fund in 2014, Steven served as the Chief Investment Officer of a single family office based in Alexandria, VA. Before that he was Managing Director of Risk at Albright Capital Management, a firm he helped launch with former Secretary of State Madeleine Albright.”

“Unusual Trading Ahead of Crypto-Treasury Deals Draws Scrutiny From U.S. Regulators” (WSJ)

“In their outreach, SEC officials have warned companies about potential violations of Regulation Fair Disclosure, some of the people said. Known as Reg FD, the rule prohibits public companies from selectively disclosing material, nonpublic information to investors, analysts and other market participants who might trade on the information.”

“Fishback Admits Sharing Confidential Greenlight Information” (Bloomberg)

“James Fishback, a former analyst at David Einhorn’s Greenlight Capital, admitted sharing confidential information and agreed to pay the hedge fund’s costs to resolve a lawsuit it filed against him.

According to an agreement filed Wednesday in Manhattan federal court, Fishback, who worked at Greenlight between 2021 and 2023, said he violated the terms of his employment by sending to a personal email account summaries of the fund’s positions and strategies as well as a document showing its entire portfolio. He also said he had an undisclosed personal trading account that invested in the same instruments as Greenlight at around the same time.”

Tweets of the Week

Until Thursday,

The Bear Cave

New? Sign Up Here

Got Feedback? Just Hit Reply

title: Qatar Reaffirms Commitment to CORSIA and ICAO's Roadmap for Sustainable Aviation | QCAA
description:
He stressed the need to accelerate the adoption and deployment of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) and Low-Carbon Aviation Fuel (LCAF), while addressing regulatory barriers that hinder their use under CORSIA.
Mr. Al-Marzooqi called for the establishment of a unified global registry for sustainable aviation fuel and highlighted the importance of strengthening international cooperation to expand accredited programs that ensure the effective implementation of the scheme.
He also expressed Qatar’s appreciation for the efforts of ICAO, its Member States, and expert groups, reaffirming the country’s commitment to continued collaboration in advancing sustainable aviation fuels in support of CORSIA.
In a second working paper, Mr. Al-Marzooqi addressed measures related to the Long-Term Global Aspirational Goal (LTAG) of achieving net-zero carbon emissions by 2050.
He underlined the critical role of Low-Carbon Aviation Fuel (LCAF) in CORSIA and emphasized the importance of adopting targeted measures to accelerate its development, production, and deployment, thereby ensuring the environmental sustainability of aviation.
text:
Mr. Mohammed Al-Marzooqi, Acting Director of the International Cooperation Department at the Qatar Civil Aviation Authority (QCAA), presented a working paper at the 42nd ICAO Assembly, outlining Qatar’s policies in support of the roadmap of the Third ICAO Conference on Aviation and Alternative Fuels (CAAF/3) and the implementation of the Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA).

He stressed the need to accelerate the adoption and deployment of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) and Low-Carbon Aviation Fuel (LCAF), while addressing regulatory barriers that hinder their use under CORSIA. He further emphasized that these efforts must be advanced in a manner that does not impose additional financial burdens on airlines.

Mr. Al-Marzooqi called for the establishment of a unified global registry for sustainable aviation fuel and highlighted the importance of strengthening international cooperation to expand accredited programs that ensure the effective implementation of the scheme.

He also expressed Qatar’s appreciation for the efforts of ICAO, its Member States, and expert groups, reaffirming the country’s commitment to continued collaboration in advancing sustainable aviation fuels in support of CORSIA.

In a second working paper, Mr. Al-Marzooqi addressed measures related to the Long-Term Global Aspirational Goal (LTAG) of achieving net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. He underlined the critical role of Low-Carbon Aviation Fuel (LCAF) in CORSIA and emphasized the importance of adopting targeted measures to accelerate its development, production, and deployment, thereby ensuring the environmental sustainability of aviation.

title: TruAlt Bioenergy ipo date, Share Price Target Tomorrow, 2025, 2026, 2030
description:
TruAlt Bioenergy IPO Details TruAlt Bioenergy Share Price Target Tomorrow (Listing day price) The company controls its costs well, which helps it earn more money.
TruAlt Bioenergy Share Price Target 2025 It is one of India’s main ethanol producers.
In 2025, its share price target would be ₹865, as per stock market analysts.
TruAlt Bioenergy share price Target 2030 Its production units follow a zero-discharge policy, so no water or waste is released into the environment.
TruAlt Bioenergy earnings results (Financials) Is TruAlt Bioenergy stock good to buy?
text:
TruAlt Bioenergy is a fast-growing biofuel company. It makes ethanol in its five Karnataka plants for the government’s fuel blending program, and it also makes compressed biogas (CBG) from farm waste. The company is now moving into new areas like 2G ethanol, sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) for aeroplanes, and biochemicals. It works with GAIL to build more CBG plants and with Sumitomo Corporation to develop big bioenergy projects. Besides clean energy, it also runs programs to help farmers and local communities with health, farming support, and development activities.

What is TruAlt Bioenergy Ltd IPO?

TruAlt Bioenergy was established in 2012 in Bengaluru, Karnataka, by Prashanth Prakash and Vikram Sakhuja. It is one of India’s main biofuel companies, producing ethanol, which is used for blending with petrol and compressed biogas used as a clean fuel. The company has a good share in India’s ethanol market, about 3.6%. Its branch, Leafiniti Bioenergy, supplies compressed biogas. It supports government plans for clean and renewable energy and is also working on future projects like advanced ethanol, fuel for aeroplanes, and eco-friendly chemicals, making it an important company in India’s green energy field.

TruAlt Bioenergy IPO Details

TruAlt Bioenergy Share Price Target Tomorrow (Listing day price)

The company controls its costs well, which helps it earn more money. It still has some debt, but its savings and reserves are increasing, making its financial position stronger. Cash coming in from its services shows the company is managing its business smoothly. Overall, it is becoming financially stronger with growing revenue, higher profits, and better efficiency, though it needs to carefully manage its debt.

TruAlt Bioenergy Share Price Target 2025

It is one of India’s main ethanol producers. Its factories work almost at full capacity, supplying a large part of the ethanol used in India. This allows the company to meet the growing demand for ethanol, which is supported by government programs to reduce oil use. It earns a steady income and strengthens its position in India’s biofuel industry. In 2025, its share price target would be ₹865, as per stock market analysts.

According to stock market analysts, its share price would be between ₹347 to ₹865 in 2025.

TruAlt Bioenergy share price Target 2026

It runs several distillery plants in Karnataka, mainly using molasses, a thick syrup left after sugar is made from sugarcane, and sugar syrup as raw materials. Its location helps the company to get these materials and keep production running smoothly. Relying on these materials also helps maintain high quality, meet industry standards, and provide ethanol for different uses, such as blending with fuel and other industrial purposes. In 2026, its share price target would be ₹1352, as per stock market analysts.

Its share price would be between ₹830 to ₹1352 in 2026, as per stock market analysts.

Share price Target 2027

The company gets its raw materials, sugar syrup, sugarcane juice, and molasses from sugar plants owned by its promoter group. The large use of these materials shows the company’s large production scale. It depends less on outside sources and can keep costs stable, which is important since raw material prices can affect profits by managing its own supply. This approach makes the company stronger, more reliable, and better prepared for the future. In 2027, its share price target would be ₹1882, as per stock market analysts.

According to stock market analysts, its share price would be between ₹1337 to ₹1882 in 2027.

Share price Target 2028

The company uses modern methods like special distillation and dehydration systems to make ethanol. It also has large fermenters and cooling towers to run production efficiently. These technologies increase ethanol output, save energy, and reduce waste. Using modern equipment allows TruAlt to keep its products high in quality while lowering costs, helping the company stay competitive and successful in the biofuel industry. In 2028, its share price target would be ₹2434, as per stock market analysts.

Its share price would be between ₹1857 to ₹2434 in 2028, as per stock market analysts.

Share price Target 2029

In its compressed biogas-making process, it uses modern compressors and purification systems. The CBG plant is built as a “no waste discharge” facility, reusing by-products from ethanol production like spent wash to make biogas, use as boiler fuel, or turn into methane. The company cuts emissions and water use, keeping its operations in line with environmental rules and standards in the biofuel industry. In 2029, its share price target would be ₹2954, as per stock market analysts.

According to stock market analysts, its share price would be between ₹2390 to ₹2954 in 2029.

TruAlt Bioenergy share price Target 2030

Its production units follow a zero-discharge policy, so no water or waste is released into the environment. Water from distillation is reused, and moisture from spent wash is recycled for fermentation. This careful use of water makes production more eco-friendly and reduces the need for fresh water. It not only reduces its environmental impact but also saves money on water and waste management. In 2030, its share price target would be ₹3474, as per stock market analysts.

Its share price would be between ₹2900 to ₹3474 in 2030, as per stock market analysts.

Share price Target 2040

It also provides Extra Neutral Alcohol to companies that make Indian-made foreign liquor. It works with well-known brands like John Distilleries, InBrew Beverages, Amrut Distilleries, and Elite Vintage Winery India Private Limited. Supplying alcohol for beverages goes along with its fuel ethanol business, which creates steady demand and helps the company earn consistent income across its different operations. In 2040, its share price target would be ₹5247, as per stock market analysts.

According to stock market analysts, its share price would be between ₹4677 to ₹5247 in 2040.

Share Price Target 2050

Its revenue has grown significantly over the past few years, due to higher production and rising market demand. The company has become stronger and more stable in India’s biofuel industry. This consistent growth shows that it plans carefully and manages its resources well, putting it in a good position to continue growing in ethanol, biogas, and other areas of bioenergy. In 2050, its share price target would be ₹5874, as per stock market analysts.

Its share price would be between ₹5324 to ₹5874 in 2050, as per stock market analysts.

Should I buy TruAlt Bioenergy stock?

It is India’s top ethanol producer and is also working on biogas, aviation fuel, and petrol pumps. The company is making good money and profits, but it has some risks like heavy loans, depending too much on government rules, and relying on only a few plants and big buyers. The company could grow well because India is pushing for clean fuel, but it is also risky, so it’s safer to invest only a small amount instead of a big one.

TruAlt Bioenergy earnings results (Financials)

Is TruAlt Bioenergy stock good to buy? (bull case & bear case)

Bull Case:

The company earned ₹1,907 crore in revenue in FY25 and a net profit of ₹146.6 crore.

Its operating profit margin (EBITDA) improved from 14% in FY23 to 16.2% in FY25.

Return on Equity (ROE) is around 28%, which is higher than many other companies in this sector.

It has a big ethanol capacity of 2,000 KLPD, with about 1,800 KLPD already running, making it the largest producer in India.

The company is also moving into biogas, aviation fuel, and fuel retailing, which can bring more business in the future.

Bear Case:

It’s 80% of its revenue comes from ethanol, so changes in government rules or raw material prices can hurt profits.

The company has loans of about ₹1,557 crore compared to equity of ₹769 crore, giving it a high debt-to-equity ratio of ~2.0.

Even though it has a capacity of 2,000 KLPD, it is not using the full amount yet, which reduces earnings.

TruAlt Bioenergy IPO Promoter Holding

Vijaykumar Murugesh Nirani, Vishal Nirani and Sushmitha Vijaykumar Nirani are the company promoters.

Objects of the Issue (TruAlt Bioenergy IPO Objectives)

₹150.68 crore will be used to upgrade the ethanol plant (300 KLPD at TBL Unit 4) so it can also use grains as raw material.

₹425.00 crore will be used for the company’s day-to-day business needs.

The rest will be used for the company’s general purposes.

TruAlt Bioenergy ipo gmp

Conclusion

It is a leading biofuel company in India that makes ethanol, compressed biogas, and is also working on aviation fuel and eco-friendly chemicals. It has several plants in Karnataka and is earning more money while running more efficiently. The company gets support from the government, works with big companies, and helps farmers and local communities. But it has some risks because it depends mostly on ethanol, has a lot of debt, and is not using all its production capacity. Overall, it can grow well in India’s green energy sector, but it is safer to invest only a small amount instead of a large one.

title: Malaysia Hosts Groundbreaking World Tourism Day 2025 Celebrations With Global Leaders ...
description:
World Tourism Day 2025 in Malaysia marked a significant milestone in the global tourism industry, with leaders uniting to advocate for sustainable transformation in travel.
A Global Celebration with Local Impact The 2025 World Tourism Day celebration in Melaka was not just a ceremonial occasion; it was an active platform for discussing practical, sustainable tourism strategies.
Malaysia’s Commitment to Sustainable Tourism One of the event’s key moments was Malaysia’s announcement that it would join the UN Tourism International Network of Sustainable Tourism Observatories (INSTO).
The 7th World Tourism Conference: Shaping the Future of Travel The 7th World Tourism Conference, held in conjunction with the World Tourism Day festivities, played a pivotal role in framing global tourism discussions.
The event underscored Malaysia’s commitment to shaping a resilient and inclusive future for global tourism.
text:
World Tourism Day 2025 in Malaysia marked a significant milestone in the global tourism industry, with leaders uniting to advocate for sustainable transformation in travel. Held under the theme “Tourism and Sustainable Transformation,” the event emphasized the pivotal role of tourism in driving economic growth, fostering cultural exchange, and safeguarding the environment. As the world faces unprecedented challenges, Malaysia’s commitment to sustainability took center stage, showcasing innovative initiatives that align with global development goals. With policymakers, industry experts, and tourism leaders in attendance, the celebrations provided a platform for collaboration, aiming to shape a resilient and inclusive future for the tourism sector.

World Tourism Day 2025 was marked in the vibrant city of Melaka, Malaysia, under the theme “Tourism and Sustainable Transformation.” This global event served as a powerful reminder of tourism’s potential to catalyze economic growth, foster cultural exchange, and safeguard environmental sustainability. Hosted in partnership with Malaysia’s Ministry of Tourism, Arts, and Culture, the celebrations aligned with the 7th World Tourism Conference, bringing together leaders, policymakers, and industry experts to shape the future of tourism.

A Global Celebration with Local Impact

The 2025 World Tourism Day celebration in Melaka was not just a ceremonial occasion; it was an active platform for discussing practical, sustainable tourism strategies. Held in the UNESCO World Heritage city, which is renowned for its rich history and cultural diversity, the event attracted delegates from around the world. The city of Melaka, with its legacy as a crossroad for various cultures, proved to be an ideal setting to underscore tourism’s potential in promoting both local and global resilience.

During the event, Malaysia’s Minister of Tourism, Arts and Culture, H.E. Dato Sri Tiong King Sing, delivered a passionate speech emphasizing the critical role that tourism plays in building resilience and promoting inclusivity across societies. He welcomed the participants and highlighted Malaysia’s commitment to making tourism a catalyst for positive social and economic changes.

The opening ceremony was officiated by the Right Honourable Dato’ Sri Haji Fadillah bin Yusof, the Deputy Prime Minister of Malaysia, who conveyed Malaysia’s vision of sustainable growth. He called for stronger international cooperation and innovation to ensure that the tourism sector not only thrives but does so responsibly, aligning with environmental and social goals. His message was clear: tourism can no longer be viewed solely through an economic lens but must embrace sustainability at its core.

Malaysia’s Commitment to Sustainable Tourism

One of the event’s key moments was Malaysia’s announcement that it would join the UN Tourism International Network of Sustainable Tourism Observatories (INSTO). The country will launch a pilot project in Mersing, Johor, a move that underscores Malaysia’s commitment to developing ecotourism and advancing the sustainability agenda. The Deputy Prime Minister detailed several ongoing initiatives aimed at creating a balanced and responsible tourism framework.

Among the projects highlighted was the creation of digital nomad hubs and high-value tourism segments designed to attract long-term visitors who prioritize sustainability. He also pointed to Malaysia’s investment in sustainable aviation fuel, a vital step in reducing the carbon footprint of air travel. These efforts not only demonstrate Malaysia’s dedication to fostering responsible tourism but also to ensuring that tourism contributes to the welfare of its people and the protection of its natural resources.

A Showcase of Global and Local Collaboration

The celebrations featured a range of panel discussions, cultural showcases, and exhibitions that focused on sustainable tourism practices. One of the key discussions centered on the vital role of education and skills development in creating a sustainable tourism ecosystem. Emphasizing the need to empower women, youth, and marginalized communities, the event spotlighted how investing in education could catalyze significant change in local tourism industries worldwide.

The event also provided a space for delegates to explore how digital transformation can accelerate tourism growth while supporting local economies. Technology was discussed as a tool for enhancing the tourism experience, from improving service delivery to offering travelers personalized, sustainable options. Panelists discussed the need for a global digital infrastructure that would allow for seamless integration between the tourism sector and technology, with a focus on creating more inclusive and equitable access to tourism benefits.

Another essential aspect of the celebration was the discussion on how tourism could be a key driver of cultural heritage preservation. Delegates emphasized the importance of reinforcing cultural heritage through tourism-driven exchanges that foster mutual understanding and respect among different cultures. By facilitating such exchanges, tourism can bridge gaps between diverse communities and promote a shared vision of sustainability.

The 7th World Tourism Conference: Shaping the Future of Travel

The 7th World Tourism Conference, held in conjunction with the World Tourism Day festivities, played a pivotal role in framing global tourism discussions. The conference explored how digital transformation and community-based tourism are central to achieving the goals of “Tourism and Sustainable Transformation.” Discussions at the conference highlighted the importance of developing solutions for climate-neutral travel and emphasized how technology and innovation can help address the challenges of the tourism sector.

One of the main areas of focus was climate-neutral travel solutions. With the rise in tourism-related emissions, conference delegates discussed how the industry could implement effective measures to reduce its carbon footprint. Solutions ranging from cleaner transportation options to energy-efficient infrastructure were presented as essential steps toward achieving sustainability goals.

Furthermore, the conference explored how community-based tourism could empower local populations and ensure that tourism benefits are more equitably distributed. By placing emphasis on community ownership and participation, the conference sought to create a tourism model that is both socially and environmentally sustainable.

A Renewed Commitment to Sustainable Transformation

As the World Tourism Day 2025 celebrations came to a close, global leaders and industry experts reaffirmed their commitment to the theme of “Tourism and Sustainable Transformation.” The event successfully highlighted the tourism sector’s potential to not only drive economic development but also contribute to the protection of our cultural heritage and natural resources. Through collaboration, innovation, and responsible tourism practices, the sector can lead the charge toward a more sustainable and inclusive global future.

World Tourism Day 2025 in Malaysia highlighted the urgent need for sustainable transformation in tourism, bringing together global leaders to explore how the sector can drive economic growth, cultural exchange, and environmental protection. The event underscored Malaysia’s commitment to shaping a resilient and inclusive future for global tourism.

The 2025 celebrations in Melaka are a call to action for tourism stakeholders worldwide. They serve as a reminder that the future of tourism lies in embracing sustainability as a core principle. Malaysia’s efforts, alongside the collective commitment of international partners, underscore the importance of integrating environmental, social, and economic considerations into the tourism sector’s growth. With innovative solutions, responsible practices, and a global commitment to sustainable transformation, the tourism industry is poised to continue its journey as a force for good in shaping the world’s future.

title: Singapore re-elected to ICAO council with highest number of votes - The Business Times
description:
[SINGAPORE] The city-state has once again been elected to the council of the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), garnering the highest number of votes of any council member thus far.

text:
[SINGAPORE] The city-state has once again been elected to the council of the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), garnering the highest number of votes of any council member thus far.

Singapore was voted in at the 42nd session of the ICAO held in Montreal, Canada, on Saturday (Sep 27) evening. The country was represented by a delegation led by Acting Minister for Transport Jeffrey Siow.

In a media statement on Sunday, Siow said: “Singapore is honoured to be re-elected to the ICAO council. The strong international leadership by ICAO, with support from member states and industry, will enable governments, industry and international organisations to work together to address challenges ahead.”

In a LinkedIn post on Sunday morning, he added that Singapore had been re-elected with “a record number of votes”.

Siow, who is also senior minister of state for Finance, said: “In a world where rules matter less and small countries find it harder to exert influence, we have to work harder with like-minded partners to secure our interests. Well functioning international organisations like ICAO remain important platforms for us to build a world that Singapore can continue to do well and prosper.”

The city-state was first elected to the ICAO council in 2003 and has been a member of the body ever since.

ICAO is an agency of the United Nations that is responsible for developing and maintaining the standards for aviation, including those related to safety, air navigation and security.

Formed in 1944, it became the UN’s official aviation standards agency in 1947.

The ICAO assembly is its policymaking entity. It is made up of representatives from ICAO’s 193 member states and gathers every three years to further the organisation’s broader work, such as adopting resolutions and deciding its priorities.

The assembly also votes on the ICAO council, which is the organisation’s permanent governing body that continually sets direction and adopts standards, amongst other work.

Singapore led with 176 votes

Balloting for the council is held three times for different categories:

Countries of chief importance in air transport

Countries that make the largest contribution to the provision of facilities for international civil air navigation

States ensuring geographic representation.

The first two sections of balloting have concluded, with 22 of the 36-seat council now elected. The remainder will be voted in with the final ballot on Sep 30.

Singapore, eligible for election under the second ballot, won with 176 votes. Saudi Arabia was the second highest with 175, and Brazil was third with 167.

Russia failed to be elected. It received the lowest number of votes in the first ballot – 87 – short of the 93 required. It lost its spot in 2022, following the outbreak of the Ukraine war.

At the opening of the assembly on Sep 23, ICAO council president, Salvatore Sciacchitano, reiterated the need for strengthening oversight, modernising infrastructure and implementing the organisation’s standards, as well as accelerating towards its 2050 goal of net-zero carbon emissions.

“A system currently built to serve 4.6 billion passengers will not accommodate three times that number, unless we ensure its transformation,” he said.

title: IATA study confirms SAF technology rollout as key bottleneck to achieving net zero emissions
description:
According to the study, sufficient sustainable feedstock exists globally, meeting strict environmental standards without causing adverse land use changes, to support the required 500 million tonnes of SAF annually by 2050.
Currently, most commercial SAF production relies on hydroprocessed esters and fatty acids (HEFA) technology, which converts waste oils into fuel.
He urged industry stakeholders to accelerate investments and build the infrastructure necessary to scale up SAF production rapidly.
Energy producers and investors are called upon to align their strategies with global decarbonization goals to ensure the rapid commercialization of SAF technologies.
The study serves as a critical reminder that while SAF feedstocks are abundant, turning this potential into actual production hinges on the acceleration of technologies, infrastructure readiness, and cross-sector collaboration.
text:
The International Air Transport Association (IATA), in collaboration with Worley Consulting, released a study on September 23, 2025, confirming that the main barrier to achieving the airline industry’s goal of net zero carbon dioxide emissions by 2050 is not a shortage of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) feedstock but rather the slow pace of rollout for SAF production technologies. According to the study, sufficient sustainable feedstock exists globally, meeting strict environmental standards without causing adverse land use changes, to support the required 500 million tonnes of SAF annually by 2050.

Currently, most commercial SAF production relies on hydroprocessed esters and fatty acids (HEFA) technology, which converts waste oils into fuel. The study pointed out the need to accelerate the development of new technologies to diversify SAF production methods, especially power-to-liquid (PtL) technologies that rely on renewable electricity, green hydrogen, and carbon capture infrastructure. It also highlighted competition for biomass feedstock among various hard-to-decarbonize sectors, stressing the importance of prioritizing aviation in feedstock allocation.

IATA’s Director General, Willie Walsh, emphasized that feedstock availability should no longer be viewed as a limiting factor. He urged industry stakeholders to accelerate investments and build the infrastructure necessary to scale up SAF production rapidly. “We now have unequivocal evidence that the challenge lies in technology deployment, not feedstock,” Walsh said. “To meet net zero goals by 2050, shovels must be in the ground now.”

The study projects that biomass feedstock could sustainably supply over 300 million tonnes of bio-SAF annually by mid-century, with the remainder of the 500 million tonnes coming from PtL fuels. However, unlocking the full potential will require coordinated global policies, enhanced supply chain logistics, infrastructure investment, and technological innovation.

Marie Owens Thomsen, IATA’s Senior Vice President for Sustainability and Chief Economist, highlighted SAF’s potential to create jobs, boost local economies, and support energy security. She stressed the critical need for governments, investors, and industry stakeholders to collaborate on policy frameworks and investment incentives to de-risk projects and hasten the development of a fully functioning SAF market.

The report underscores regional leadership from key global players such as North America, Brazil, Europe, India, China, and ASEAN countries as vital to scaling up production and meeting global demand. Energy producers and investors are called upon to align their strategies with global decarbonization goals to ensure the rapid commercialization of SAF technologies.

The study serves as a critical reminder that while SAF feedstocks are abundant, turning this potential into actual production hinges on the acceleration of technologies, infrastructure readiness, and cross-sector collaboration. With only 25 years remaining to meet the ambitious net zero target, timely action and focused investments are paramount to decarbonizing the aviation sector and securing a sustainable future for air travel.
